Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bradsch Dealing with treatments including hormone therapy can ravage the body's systems and natural balance. There are ways to naturally boost the immune system, for example.We must do everything in our power to combat and mediate the onset and management of this disease. The Eastern Internal arts can offer time-proven wisdom on how we can improve our health and energy in naturally effective ways. This way we can be in charge of our own health, and without negative side-effects. We can learn techniques and principles to start to take charge of our own health. For an example of holistic tips and techniques from the Eastern Arts: https://abundantpeace_b0cb.gr8.com/ Mr Bradsch: It appears that your magical pathway to wellness will Cost $s to achieve. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor How do I now teach myself to not wake up in the middle of the night wondering and pondering "what if?" and to not wander off during the day into a mental fog of "what if?" I suggest that you add "What if I fail to wake up ever again?" to your list of "What if" neurotic concerns. I sure hope that you are never simultaneously struck by both lightning and a meteor while on your way to purchase a winning lottery ticket! A much better question to ask is: "What if I never have prostate cancer?" Perspective my friend, perspective.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Thanks, guys! Actually the surgical path report could not have been better -- so much so that my insurance wouldn't pay for my Decipher test as they didn't classify me as high risk any longer! According to the Decipher result it was a type that isn't prone to metastasize. It now turns out that a fair percentage of men with high Gleason scores are reclassified to low risk post surgery based on their genetics. No doubt the insurance companies will automatically decrease the life insurance premiums based on these Decipher test results!?!?

Posts.Title: Venting here

Posts.Content: Mr SubDenis: I see that your rather dour philosophical questioning has surfaced again. To put it bluntly: We are all dying. With each passing heartbeat, breath, blink of our eyes we are closer to the end. Since death is inevitable, we should chose to live life as fully as possible for as long as possible. I am sorry to read of another malady that you possess. I may be wrong but if you were a full career Navy submariner, then the malady that started at age 25 likely was not life threatening or career threatening. Again, you have had a most fortunate experience with prostate cancer. Many on this forum are far far less fortunate and can only wish that they had received your exact diagnosis. You did a highly commendable job researching all of the possible treatment options and settled on a treatment (HDR BT) that would work best for you - and it has! In 3 months your PSA has dropped more than 75%. At that rate, your upcoming PSA may be less than 0.1 As you say: "let's choose living!" Good luck with the next PSA. It'll be vanishing.
Posts.Title: Am I living or dying?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ANWANK I know. I am still in disbelief Disbelief is highly appropriate. Engaging in intercourse so soon is highly inappropriate. Most, if not all, urology surgeons instruct their post RP patients to "keep it in the hangar for at least 3 weeks." Celibacy is advised until healing is complete.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor ......My wife so so impressed that she signed me up for RALP next Thursday, Aug 23. And, I was greatly relieved to have made that decision...... Mr Sailor: You are obviously searching for the right treatment choice and have done an admirable amount of research into the best options. Be thankful that you have multiple options - even though you must navigate your way through the torments of arriving at the best decision. Question: Is the above quote for real or a joke? If for real, is the surgeon concerned that immediate treatment is necessary? It could border on malpractice to perform a radical prostatectomy less than 3 weeks following biopsy if there is no clinical urgency. Good luck determining the best treatment and quickly getting it completed.
Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I’m on a tour of Central Asia, and am now in Uzbekistan, where internet access appears to be unrestricted. Not so in Turkmenistan, where the Soviet-style government blocks “unacceptable” websites, even using VPN’s. Such banned sites include Facebook, Yahoo, Google, AND cancerforums.net. Why is that??? They do play favorites, blocking foxnews and drudge, while allowing cnn and msnbc. But, those are political, and, while cancer treatment discussions can sometimes have the tone of politics, the blocking of the site is puzzling. Other, similar PCa forums are allowed. Well, now we know why we never see postings from Turkmenistan �� Hmmm........ Did you have internet access to interfere with American elections while there?
Posts.Title: HUMOR - This forum blocked in Turkmenistan

Posts.Content: Please seek sound medical advice and treatment. Not to be crass but as a former poster used to say: "An erection provides no pleasure to a corpse" Be aggressive and tackle this now and don't let it tackle you.
Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed with stage III T3C

Posts.Content: There you go again Mr Subdenis....proselytizing about the woes of serious cancer as if you have experienced it. You have not. Your prostate cancer was only a minor surface scratch. In the Navy it would be defined as a close call and not a collision. In the world of dermatology, you had a small basal cell as opposed to having a metastatic melanoma lesion. If you are experiencing continued fear of prostate cancer, immediately seek professional help! End of criticism. You are an inspiring example of what every new member or visitor should follow. Once diagnosed, do lots of research and investigate every options. Decide on the best option. You accomplished this with perfection. Everything else you say rings true and is good advice that we should all take. Thank you
Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor How does one resolve this Extracapsular Extension/Disease question? This is the $64K question that your MDs must answer. To resolve any issue in life, the issue must be defined. There is only 1 way to define EPE = Surgery. Possibly this may be your answer. Good luck

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: IMO Mr Jim McCarthy falls perilously close to the category of charlatan. He should have never been allowed on stage to give a TED Talk related to being diagnosed with prostate cancer. He is on AS! He has not been affected by Prostate Cancer except for his self proclaimed grossly inappropriate psychological impacts of a disease status that is most likely 100% harmless to him. He received a gift diagnosis not a death sentence! He has not experienced any of the following either individually or in combination: Radiation Therapy, Radical Prostatectomy Surgery, Hormone Therapy; Radical Prostatectomy Surgery followed by Radiation Therapy, Any of these combined with Hormone Therapy, incontinence, erectile dysfunction, loss of masculinity during treatment and obviously not death by prostate cancer. No, he experienced no pain or suffering. He has never had to battle the disease. Rather he used his "misfortune" to snag a new girlfriend and ride off to a new start in his blue convertible. Get out the puke bags buddy!!! Instead Mr McCarthy stands in the spotlight and insipidly spews out a theme stolen from the great Al Greene: Love and Happiness. What a misguided total fool! What an insult to the members of this forum who have been truly impacted by prostate cancer. Sorry Mr SubDenis but you should remove the link to Mr McCarthy's shameful self-aggrandizing charade.
Posts.Title: Good TED talk

Posts.Content: Total emetic!

Posts.Title: William Shatner & PSA

Posts.Content: Was wondering why some here appear to be in the midst of biochemical recurrence following robotic prostatectomy with pathology reports that suggest high likelihood of cure yet just the opposite seems to be occurring. Pratoman Diagnosed at age 64 (in November, 2014), PSA 4.3 Nov 2014 BX 3 of 12 cores positive original pathology G6 10%, G6 20%, G8 (3+5), 70%. Johns Hopkins second opinion, G6, G6, G6 Surgery with Dr Ash Tewari Jan 6, 2015 [U]Post surgical pathology, stage T2c, bilateral disease, upstaged to G7(3+4) 5% of Prostate involved in Tumor. Organ confined, Margins, SV, lymph nodes (9) all negative, PNI positive PSA <.02 until (uh-oh), 2/17 .02. Then 5/17 .033, 8/17, .033, 11/17 .046, 4/17 .060[/U] Decipher score low risk, .37 MiklaDfar Age 60, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 230# 2013 PSA Jan:4.5, Mar:3.4, Jul:4.6, Oct:8.1, Nov:7.7 Normal DRE 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 09/24/2013 John Hopkins Pathology: 2/12, 5% & 10%, G3+3, 2 HGPIN 01/16/2014 RALP by Dr. Tewari, Final Path: G6, 5% involvement, neg Margins No incontinence, minimal ED issues after two weeks post-op NICE Guidance & NCCN Guidance kdb315 4/2016 prostatectomy with Dr. Tewari at Mt. Sinai (neg margins, no EPE, lymph nodes clear, +perineural invasion) 5/2016 still incontinent, ED present 5/2016 PSA 0.0 8/2016 PSA 0.1
Posts.Title: Observation, Statistics, Coincidences?

Posts.Content: I totally disagree with you Mr SubDenis. Fear is an essential self preservation mechanism. Fear becomes a problem when one is consumed by irrational fear. It becomes a major problem both for the individual and those around him/her. IMO, your expressed fear is self centered and out of line with reality. On the full spectrum of Cancer diagnoses, you have received a mere minor surface scratch. You have not been cursed with prostate cancer, rather you have been quite fortunate. If in doubt, take time to read the stories of those with advanced prostate cancer or venture to other forums such as brain and pancreatic cancers where fear is justified. Proper Perspective is what is most important. I fully agree with your position on dignity and gratitude. Together all of us have a lot for which to be thankful. Thank you for your service in the U.S. Navy as a member of an elite squad where Bravery never permits Fear surface.
Posts.Title: Fear is a liar
